content.text: Define power
Use the definition of power to show that the SI base units of power are \(\mathrm{kgm}^2 \mathrm{s}^{-3}\)
The intensity \(I\) of a sound wave moving through a gas is given by
where \(f\) is the frequency of the wave,
A is the amplitude of the wave,
v is the speed of the wave
and k is a constant that depends on the gas
Determine the SI base units of \(k\)
SI base units   .........
Show that the vertical component of the tension in the string is 2.4 N
By taking moments about the hinge, determine the weight \(W\) of the beam
Calculate the horizontal component of the force exerted on the beam by the hinge
The spring obeys Hooke's law and has an elastic potential energy of 0.32 J
Calculate the compression of the spring
compression =   .........  \(m\)
Calculate the decrease in the gravitational potential energy of the block for its movement from A to B
decrease in gravitational potential energy = .................................................... J
Use your answer in (c)(i) and conservation of energy to determine the speed of the block at point A
By reference to the force on the block, explain why the horizontal component of the velocity of the block remains constant as it moves from A to B
The block passes through point A at time \(t_{\mathrm{A}}\) and arrives at point B at time \(t_{\mathrm{B}}\)

On Fig. 2.3, sketch a graph to show the variation of the magnitude of the vertical component \(\nu_{\mathrm{Y}}\) of the velocity of the block with time \(t\) from \(t = t_{\mathrm{A}}\) to \(t = t_{\mathrm{B}}\). Numerical values of \(\nu_{\mathrm{Y}}\) are not required
The string is cut so that the spring extends upwards. This causes the beam to rotate and launch the block into the air. The block reaches its maximum height and then falls back to the ground
Fig. 2.2 shows part of the path of the block in the air shortly before it hits the horizontal ground
The block is at a height of \(0.090 \text{m}\) above the ground when it passes through point A. The block has a kinetic energy of \(0.044 \text{J}\) when it hits the ground at point B
Air resistance is negligible
A rigid uniform beam of weight \(W\) is connected to a fixed support by a hinge, as shown in Fig. 2.1

A compressed spring exerts a total force of 8.2 N vertically upwards on the horizontal beam. A block of weight \(0.30 \text{N}\) rests on the beam. The right-hand end of the beam is connected to the ground by a string at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The tension in the string is \(4.8 \text{N}\). The distances along the beam are shown in Fig. 2.1
The beam is in equilibrium. Assume that the hinge is frictionless
State Newton's second law of motion
the resultant force on the block
resultant force =   .........  N
the force \(X\)

Fig. 3.3
A block is pulled in a straight line along a rough horizontal surface by a varying force \(X,\) as shown in Fig. 3.1
Air resistance is negligible. Assume that the frictional force exerted on the block by the surface is constant and has magnitude 2.0N
The variation with time \(t\) of the momentum \(p\) of the block is shown in Fig. 3.2
By using the definitions of pressure and density, show that
where \(p\) is the pressure due to the liquid that is exerted on the base of the beaker and \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall
Suggest why the equation in (a) does not give the total pressure on the base of the beaker
Fig. 4.2 shows the variation of the total pressure inside the liquid with depth \(x\) below the surface
Determine the density of the liquid
A solid cylinder is held stationary by a wire so that the base of the cylinder is level with the surface of the liquid, as shown in Fig. 4.3
The cylinder has length \(4.0 \times 10^{- 2} \text{m}\) and cross-sectional area \(3.7 \times 10^{- 4} \text{m}^2\). The tension in the wire is \(0.53 \text{N}\)
The cylinder is now lowered and then held stationary by the wire so that the top of the cylinder is level with the surface of the liquid
Calculate the new tension in the wire
tension =   .........  N
A beaker in air contains a liquid. The base of the beaker is in contact with the liquid and has area \(A\), as shown in Fig. 4.1
The liquid has density \(\rho\) and fills the beaker to a depth \(h\)
State the name of the principal region of the electromagnetic spectrum for the wave
Calculate the frequency, in THz, of the wave
frequency =   .........  THz
An electromagnetic wave in a vacuum has a wavelength of \(8.4 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}\)
The light waves emerging from the two slits are coherent
State what is meant by coherent
Calculate the separation \(a\) of the slits
An arrangement that uses a double slit to demonstrate the interference of light from a laser is shown in Fig. 5.1

The light from the laser has a wavelength of \(6.2 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}\) and is incident normally on the slits. The separation of the two slits is \(a\). The slits and screen are parallel and separated by a distance of \(2.8 \text{m}\)
An interference pattern of bright fringes and dark fringes is formed on the screen. The distance on the screen across 8 bright fringes is \(22 \text{mm}\), as illustrated in Fig. 5.2
Calculate the difference in the distances (the path difference) from each slit to the centre of fringe Q
difference in the distances =   .........  m
State the phase difference between the light waves meeting at the centre of fringe R
phase difference =   .........

Fringe P is the central bright fringe of the interference pattern in **(b)**. Fringe Q and fringe R are the nearest dark fringe and the nearest bright fringe respectively to the right of fringe P, as shown in Fig. 5.2
Show that the number density of the free electrons in the wire is \(8.5 \times 10^{28} \text{m}^{-3}\)
Calculate the average drift speed of the free electrons
average drift speed =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-1}\)

A metal wire in a circuit has a length of \(1.8 \text{m}\) and a cross-sectional area of \(1.5 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}^2\). The total number of free electrons (charge carriers) in the wire is \(2.3 \times 10^{23}\)
There is a current in the wire so that a charge of \(172 \text{C}\) moves past a fixed point in the wire in a time of 2.5 minutes
Calculate the current in the resistor of resistance \(5800 \Omega\)
current =   .........  A
Calculate the resistance of the thermistor
resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
The initial energy stored in the battery is \(2.6 \times 10^{4} \text{ J}\)
Assume that the e.m.f. of the battery is constant
Determine the final energy stored in the battery after a charge of \(330 \text{C}\) has moved through it
final stored energy =   .........  J
the temperature of the thermistor
the current in the thermistor
the potential difference across the thermistor
The environmental conditions change causing an increase in the resistance of the thermistor
State whether there is a decrease, increase or no change to:
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(9.6 \text{V}\) and negligible internal resistance is connected in series with two fixed resistors and a thermistor, as shown in Fig. 7.1
The fixed resistors have resistances of \(3400 \Omega\) and \(5800 \Omega\). The reading on the voltmeter in the circuit is \(6.0 \text{V}\)
nucleus Z
nucleus X
By comparing the number of protons in each nucleus, state and explain whether the charge of nucleus Y is less than, greater than or the same as the charge of:
Use the principle of conservation of momentum to explain why nucleus Y cannot be stationary immediately after the decay of nucleus X
An isolated stationary nucleus X decays by emitting an \(\alpha\) -particle to form a nucleus Y
Nucleus Y and nucleus Z are isotopes of the same element
